comments.text:
Pit Bulls actually used to be called "nanny dogs" because they get along so 
well with kids. They were known as being great family pets before they got 
the reputation as fighters. The problem is that if one pit does something 
bad it is all over the news, but no one mentions the thousand other pits in 
the area that are basically big affectionate mushes.﻿

comments.text:
I love this video because people are so scared of dog like pit bulls 
because they are portrayed as evil, vicious dogs, when in reality they are 
really sweet dogs. Dogs are born innocent and good but can be trained by 
bad people to become bad themselves, just like humans. Never blame a dog 
breed for what people have taught them to act like. I have a pitbull and he 
is one of the sweetest dogs out there. All he wants are kisses and to 
cuddle. So really, if you are gonna judge a dog, judge their owner first 
because where else do you think they learned it from?﻿

comments.author: Erwin Smith

comments.text:
All modern dogs are products of centuries of animal husbandry. They've all 
been bred to associate with humans and be useful companions. The problem 
arises when you have an inept owner. Owner either hasn't established 
themselves as the alpha or they give off social cues that put the animal on 
edge. Keeping an energetic breed cooped up all day also loads them with 
energy that needs to get worked off. If you combine all of that, you can 
have a dog that thinks it's in charge, it's owner (part of its pack) is 
threatened, and enough energy to go 20 rounds in a boxing ring... that's 
trouble. Any dog can be aggressive, but it happens due to owner neglect, 
abuse, etc.﻿
comments.author: therandomdot

comments.author: Melanie Diaz

comments.text:
When I was in like fourth grade I was walking home with a friend when we 
saw this pit bull that had escaped from it's yard barking at the passing 
cars and the big groups of kids and their parents walking home from school. 
Everyone went out of their way to ignore him, despite the fact that he was 
right next to a road with heavy traffic and was in serious danger of being 
hit, and my friend was kind of freaking out and wanted to go the long way 
home, but at the time I had no idea that pit bulls had such a bad rep, and 
I grew up with St. Bernard's and family friends with German Shepherds, Bull 
Mastiffs, and Rottweiler's, and I've never been afraid of dogs, so I just 
got on my knees a few yards away from him and patted my knees, and just 
like that he went from this scary, growling animal to this really sweet and 
really scared puppy. He tucked his tail between his legs and crawled toward 
me and fell on his back and wanted me to rub his belly. He immediately 
stopped being aggressive and just sort of hid behind my knees, and after a 
few minutes he was able to calm down and started feeling safe enough to 
start wagging his tail and trying to play. I was able to find his address 
on his collar and walked him safely across traffic and take him back home 
before anyone could call animal control or he could hurt himself. He 
actually looked a lot like the lighter pit bull in this video - I can't 
remember his actual name because since it wasn't on his tag I started 
calling him Big Mac, and that's what I now remember him as. I'm not saying 
that what I did was smart or that people who are apprehensive around pit 
bulls are bad people, because it really could have gone a totally different 
way under certain circumstances, but it just goes to show that these dogs 
do have flip sides, like every other animal they're capable of 
being dangerous but they can also be very sociable, and it's really not 
fair to judge them just because they sometimes resort to aggression when 
they feel scared or feel like they're being backed into a corner.﻿
comments.author: Seeley Marie
